title: Beijing’s Risky Assault on China’s Most Famous Billionaire
sub_head: Jack Ma’s experience may have a chilling effect on innovation if Chinese entrepreneurs come to believe a political squeeze is the price of commercial success
body:
Chinese fintech giant Ant Group Co. may need to downgrade its ambitions in the face of a still-evolving regulatory squeeze. The impact will ripple far beyond the company and has the potential to damage incentives for innovation and entrepreneurship in China over the long term.
Ant was set for a colossal $34.4 billion initial public offering until late last year, but will now instead turn itself into a financial holding company, according to people familiar with the matter. That would make it subject to higher capital requirements and probably dramatically slower growth.
What is happening is emblematic of two trends. The first is Beijing’s desire to get a tighter grip on China’s booming online financial services industry.
Ant has had a revolutionary impact on Chinese consumer finance—creating what was at one point the largest money-market fund in the world—helping expand access to loans for small borrowers. That’s not without drawbacks, however, including serious financial stability concerns. Ant’s capital-light model of originating loans for banks for a fee without taking on much risk itself created a clear potential for abuse.
But the second trend is a political culture that can’t brook alternative centers of influence.
